Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports the conference Seminar on Stochastic Processes(SSP) 2013 to be held at Duke University Campus and jointly hosted by Duke University and the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill on March 14-16, 2013. These seminars have been held annually since 1981; they have become the most important regular conference series for probabilists in North America. They bring together a diverse group of accomplished researchers and young investigators in probability and stochastic processes. The primary goal is to provide a platform for the dissemination of the most recent significant progress in research, and to enable participants to discuss their work in an informal atmosphere. Starting in 2013, SSP will include additional activities for new researchers to be held the day before the main Seminar talks. In 2013 these will take the form of a tutorial delivered by a speaker selected by the Probability Subcommittee of the IMS New Researchers Committee.

The Seminar on Stochastic Processes is a fixture in probability, and many of the most prominent probabilists make a habit of attending it every year. The morning invited presentations provide a platform for the latest developments in the field. Moreover, the informal format of the afternoon sessions gives graduate students and young researchers a unique opportunity to expose themselves to the most recent research trends by engaging in high level open discussions, and by offering the opportunity to present their own research to leaders in their field. The synergy made possible by this original formula is very rarely found in more traditional meetings. Financial support to attend the conference will preferentially be given to graduate students, postdocs, women, and minorities, as well as to junior faculty who may not otherwise be able to attend the conference.


Conference information can be found at http://sites.duke.edu/ssp2013/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The funds from this grant supported  the 2013 Seminar on Stochastic Processes(SSP) that was jointly hosted by Duke University and the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill on March 14-16, 2013. These seminars have been held annually since 1981; they have become the most important regular conference series for probabilists in North America. They bring together a diverse group of accomplished researchers and young investigators in probability and stochastic processes. The primary goal is to provide a platform for the dissemination of the most recent significant progress in research, and to enable participants to discuss their work in an informal atmosphere. Starting in 2013, SSP also included additional activities for new researchers that were held the day before the main Seminar talks.  Project supported travel and local expenses for invited speakers and over 35 new researchers. The meeting provided a forum for exchange of ideas at the research frontiers in the area of probability. In particular it gave young specialists and senior researchers an opportunity to discuss and work on recent advances in stochastic processes. In 2013 additional activities for new researchers took the form of a  three hours long tutorial directed towards new researchers. The tutorial lecturer was Professor Andrea Montanari who gave a talk on `Statistical mechanics on sparse and random graphs'. On March 14, Professor Tom Kurtz delivered the Kai-Lai Chung lecture on `Particle representations for stochastic partial differential equations'. Three one hour plenary lectures were also delivered by Professors Allan Sly, Marta Sanz-Sole and Frederi Viens from March 14-16. Forty five new researchers gave short contributed presentations as well. In addition there was a panel discussion on the 14th  on topics related to professional career development of new researchers such as grant funding mechanisms, publishing papers, job applications etc.  The workshop attracted over one hundred participants from the probability theory community who attended the research lectures given by plenary speakers and contributed talks of the new researchers. Additional activities supported by this award include Fourth and Fifth Southeastern Probability Conferences held in May 2014 and 2015, respectively,  at Duke University. Some of the speakers and participants in this conference were supported by this award.

Broader impacts: The conferences gave an excellent forum for new researchers to present their work to a large audience in the probability theory community. Plenary talks and tutorial lecture gave audience a view of cutting edge research in the field. The panel discussion at the SSP workshop on Thursday afternoon on topics related to professional career development of new researchers such as grant funding mechanisms, publishing papers, job applications etc. was very helpful to new researchers and will have a long term inpact on their research careers.
